Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[build] Use .csproj files, not .mdproj files" (#1271) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
(The extension is a lie!)

Commit 6fd330df lists the ideal build scenario:

> Load Xamarin.Android.sln into your IDE and Build the project.

We're not there yet.

What *prevents* that? In part, the *existence* of `.mdproj` files.
While `msbuild`-at-the-command-line doesn't care about project
extensions, *Visual Studio* **does***. Thus, the presence of `.mdproj`
files results in Visual Studio showing an "(incompatible)" message
next to the project, and it refuses to load the project.

Improve things by renaming all `.mdproj` files to `.csproj` files, and
then adding a `$(TargetFrameworkVersion)` value to each of them (as
Visual Studio requires `$(TargetFrameworkVersion)` in order to load
the project file).

With these two changes -- change extension, set
`$(TargetFrameworkVersion)` -- Visual Studo 2017 will load all of the
projects in the solution without showing the "(incompatible)" message.

Note: Visual Studio caches project state within the `.vs` directory
(stored in the toplevel checkout directory). If `Xamarin.Android.sln`
has been previously loaded into Visual Studio, you will need to do one
of the following to allow Visual Studio to load the projects:

 1. Right-click the project within the Solution Explorer, then click
    Reload. Repeat for all such projects. Or,
 2. Exit Visual Studio, and delete the `.vs` folder. When Visual
    Studio next loads the project, the projects will load.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix build with msbuild on Linux" (#1270) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
XA's Makefile exports the OS environment variable set to output of the `uname -s` 
command which returns the operating system's name. On macOS it will return
`Darwin`, on Linux `Linux` etc. MSBuild (the build system, not the command)
defines a standard property `$(OS)` which names the operating system kind -
`Windows_NT` on Windows and `Unix` on *nix systems.

Our project and target files (also a large set of them from e.g. Mono) use the
property to check whether they are running on Unix or Windows and they rely on
the property's value to be set correctly to make the right decisions.
MSBuild (the system) supports setting of properties from the command line but it
also takes their values from the process environment. However, it appears
there's a major difference between Mono's xbuild (which is used by default by
XA) and msbuild in that xbuild "protects" the `OS` property by NOT using the
OS environment property to set its value, while msbuild sets the property from
the environment variable. This results in the property to have the value of
`Darwin` on macOS and `Linux` on Linux and it happens to work (more or less)
correctly on macOS because we do check for `'$(OS)' == 'Darwin' or '$(OS)' == 'Unix')` 
in a few places while we do NOT check for `'$(OS)' == 'Linux')`
anywhere. All this together breaks XA build on Linux in a few places.

This patch makes the msbuild build (`make MSBUILD=msbuild`) to work on Linux by
renaming the Make `$(OS)` variable to `$(CURRENT_OS)` and thus "protecting" the
standard value of the `$(OS)` property during the build.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add GetAndroidDependencies Target" (#1269) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
We need to add a `GetAndroidDependencies` target which will output an `@(AndroidDependency)` with `%(AndroidDependency.Version)` metadata.

Valid component names are:

* platform
* build-tool
* platform-tool
* tool

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] missing EmbeddedResource.LogicalName for __AndroidLibraryProjects__" (#1239) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes #1235

There seems to be a bug in msbuild [1] where if you create
an item inside a task and the task is skipped, the metadata
is not created for the item.

So we get into a situation where our `__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip`
does not contain the correct LogicalName. As a result our
extraction process cannot find the resource, and builds fail.

This commit spits out the code that created the zip file into
its own target `_CreateManagedLibraryResourceArchive`. This means
we can skip this new target it needed. However the target
which creates the item `_AddLibraryProjectsEmbeddedResourceToProject`
can now run for every build. This will ensure that the metadata is
always created.

Also added a unit test.

[1] https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/netframework/en-US/259271d8-a3fc-4a9b-9e3a-fecad8f6f63f/potential-bug-with-createitem-task-and-additionalmetadata?forum=msbuild

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Issues with incremental build of resources (missing EmbeddedResource.LogicalName for __AndroidLibraryProjects__)" (#1235) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Sorry, no clear steps to reproduce. Problem happens after various incremental builds.

`_AddLibraryProjectsEmbeddedResourceToProject` creates an `EmbeddedResource`:

```
Task "CreateItem" (TaskId:5014)
  Task Parameter:Include=obj\Android-OpenGLES\__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip (TaskId:5014)
  Task Parameter:AdditionalMetadata=LogicalName=__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip (TaskId:5014)
  Output Item(s): 
      EmbeddedResource=
          obj\Android-OpenGLES\__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip
                  LogicalName=__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip (TaskId:5014)
```

However, if `_AddLibraryProjectsEmbeddedResourceToProject` inputs/outputs are already up to date, it will add it without the `LogicalName`:
```
5>Skipping target "_AddLibraryProjectsEmbeddedResourceToProject" because all output files are up-to-date with respect to the input files.
5>Input files: C:\DEV\xenko2\sources\engine\SiliconStudio.Xenko.Engine\obj\Android-OpenGLES\res\layout\game.xml
5>Output files: obj\Android-OpenGLES\__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip
```
result:
```
EmbeddedResource=
    obj\Android-OpenGLES\__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip
            OriginalItemSpec=obj\Android-OpenGLES\__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip
            TargetPath=obj\Android-OpenGLES\__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip
```

Then, `CreateCSharpManifestResourceName` ends up creating a `LogicalName` which contains the root namespace:
```
obj\Android-OpenGLES\__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip
    LogicalName=SiliconStudio.Xenko.obj.Android_OpenGLES.__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip
```

As a result, `ResolveLibraryProjectImports` from Xamarin can't find the expected `__AndroidLibraryProjects__.zip` file since it has another name.
Resources collides and it results in a runtime crash when loading resource.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Tasks] Add aot to the list of valid profilers" (#1253) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
With this change it is possible to build an apk containing `aot`
profiler module (libmono-profiler-aot.so shared library) and profile
the app with it. It can enabled by setting `mono.debug.profile`
property to `aot` on the device or emulator.

Note that the `aot` profiler saves the data during the mono
runtime shutdown. So one way (only way?) to get the data is to call
`System.Environment.Exit` to end the XA app. Currently  there is
an issue with Java.Interop, where during the shutdown we get
an unhandled exception and thus the shutdown process doesn't
finish, which means the profile output is not written to the file.
Hopefully I can fix that soon.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "What about ubiquitous things for Xamarin.Forms?" (#1789) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Thanks to Flutter, a lot of xamarin-fans are seriously considering ubiquitous looking things,@Mike-EEE, but indeed there is avalonia for years, @kekekeks.

Thanks to Skixam, @adamped, a sample project aimed to create another platform like flutter.

A lot of guys love and enjoy Forms, i only believe that there should be a set of tools for ubiquitous UX, which is to boost the ecosystem for forms and not to compete or to replace it. My suggestions are below
     1)UbiGrid, UbiStackPanel, UbiLabel...... Ubis are better than a new platform, because it could be used together with existing forms' api without any change.

     2)For nesting, "solo-ubi", there should only be one renderer just like skixam' idea.

```
<UbiGrid>
    <UbiStackPanel>
        <UbiLabel/>
        <UbiButton/>
        <UbiLabel/>
    </UbiStackPanel>
</UbiGrid>
```
  
    3)For nesting, "non->ubi", renderers should be as many as root-ubis, below there should be 3

```
<Grid>
    <StackPanel>
        <UbiLabel/>
        <UbiButton/>
        <UbiLabel/>
    </StackPanel>
</Grid>
```

     4)For nesting, "ubi-root", there should be 2 renderers,  one skiaView renderer and one other render for nonUbis layout.

```
<UbiGrid>
    <UbiStackPanel>
        <Grid>
           <UbiButton/>
        </Grid>
        <UbiButton/>
        <UbiLabel/>
    </UbiStackPanel>
</UbiGrid>
```

     5)Skia is good, but to decouple it from ubi is better. Skia is only for 2D, other engines should also be given the hook. So, there will be things like this.

```
<UbiGrid Engine="Skia">
    <UbiStackPanel Engine="Urho">
        <Grid>
           <UbiButton/>
        </Grid>
        <UbiButton/>
        <UbiLabel/>
    </UbiStackPanel>
</UbiGrid>
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Can't use .NET Standard with MasterDetailPage consistently" (#1787) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
When I create blank Xamarin.Forms project with .NET Standard shared library and I replace default MainPage with new MasterDetailPage created from New File selector. Then when I use Live Player it compiles and correctly shows on android phone. HOWEVER, when I create folder for example "Views" and move all classes that were created with MasterDetailPage and try to compile it again I get
```
Start (App1.Android, LGE Nexus 5 Player, ).
Attempting connection to debug address: 192.168.88.227:37847.
Connected to: 192.168.88.227:37847.
Deploying C:\dev\csharp\App1\App1\App1.Android\App1.Android.csproj...
Got device info: LGE Nexus 5 Player (Android) @ 192.168.88.227:37847
Synchronizing files...
Building and running...
Built with 1 messages.
(1,1): error: Dependent project App1.csproj failed to build, using old version.
Failed to debug your app.
```
But the craziest thing is, that when I move those MasterDetailPage files back from Views folder it is still not deployable and gives the same message... REALLY ANNOYING. I just spent 4 hours trying to figure out why my app couldn't be send to Live Player and I narrowed it down to this ridiculousness.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create Blank Xamarin Forms with .NET Standard shared library via New Project, Xamarin.Forms Template
2. Remove MainPage.*
3. Add MasterDetailPage named for example AppMasterDetailPage, it creates like 7 files (root, master, detail and menuitem pages and class)
4. Fix reference in App.xaml.cs from removed MainPage to AppMasterDetailPage
5. Deploy via Live Player and verify that it works
6. Create folder "Views" and move all AppMasterDetailPage* files into it
7. Deploy via Live Player and verify that it doesn't work
8. Move AppMasterDetailPage* files from folder "Views" back into projectroot folder
9. Deploy via Live Player and verify that it doesn't work

### Expected Behavior
I would at least expected that when I have it in one state that works and I get it back to that state it works again. And definitely not that it doesn't work afterwards...

### Actual Behavior
Obviously I would expect it to work from projectroot always and also from Views folder. Why doesn't it work?

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 2.5.0.122203
- Last known good version: dunno
- IDE: VS2017 15.5.6
- Platform Target Frameworks: 
  - Android: none works, tried few of them
- Nuget Packages: NETStandard.Library, Xamarin.Forms
- Affected Devices: dunno Android LGE Nexus 5 Player

### Screenshots
![](https://i.imgur.com/itpjnGA.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ControlTemplate's visible but transparent views mask user taps" (#1758) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues

### Description

Given an app that uses a `ControlTemplate` to provide functionality, if the `ControlTemplate` has a `ContentView` above its `ContentPresenter` (i.e. after it in the XAML), the `ContentView` masks user taps unless its `IsVisible` property is set to false.

This is a breaking change from previous versions of Xamarin.Forms, where it was sufficient to set the `ContentView`'s `Opacity` to `0.0` (transparent) and events would pass through to views underneath.

### Steps to Reproduce

Please see repro app included with this report. 

The app has two pages labelled "Failing" and "Working".

Tap the button on the "Failing" page and nothing happens.
Tap the button on the "Working" page and an alert appears.

Both pages have a `ControlTemplate` with a `ContentPresenter` underneath a `ContentView`. 

On the "Failing" page's `ControlTemplate` the `ContentView`'s `Opacity` is set to `0.0`, while its `IsVisible` is set to `true`.
On the "Working" page's `ControlTemplate` the `ContentView`'s `Opacity` is set to `0.0`, while its `IsVisible` is set to `false`.

### Expected Behavior

In previous versions of Xamarin Forms, both pages would work, i.e. `IsVisible` would have no effect on the pass-through of events to layers beneath the top `ContentView`.

### Actual Behavior

The `ContentView` has to have its `IsVisible` set to `false` in addition to `Opacity` set to `0.0` in order for events to pass through to layers underneath.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 2.5.0.122203
- Last known good version: At least 2 releases prior
- IDE: VS Mac
- Platform Target Frameworks: === Visual Studio Community 2017 for Mac (Preview) ===

Version 7.4 Preview (7.4 build 884)
Installation UUID: 6c4f5aaf-4e3e-4121-aa23-b12d8d6df997

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`SceneKit.SCNPhysicsWorld.ConvexSweepTest` method doesn't work properly" (#3383) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download a project
2. Open a `Fox2.Shared/Character.cs` file and look at the line 787. Put a breakpoint to the line 789.
3. Run the project
4. Run forward using control on the bottom left corner. 

### Expected Behavior
The `ConvexSweepTest` method return collision contacts.

### Actual Behavior
The `ConvexSweepTest` method doesn't return anything. Output is empty.

### Environment

- https://gist.github.com/mykyta-bondarenko-gl/eb7a5511ea20a0de790cb582da3b0768

### Build Logs

- Device log (when method should returns collisions)
 https://gist.github.com/mykyta-bondarenko-gl/3d8d97263787d6503ea008bb6272f286

### Frequency of Reproduction

Happens every time

### Example Project 

[Link to the project](https://github.com/mykyta-bondarenko-gl/private-samples/tree/fox-2-scenekit/ios11/Fox2)

Closed issue "[XI] ImageInverterExtn app displays a blank app on simulator " (#3371) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

 1. Download and open https://developer.xamarin.com/samples/monotouch/ios8/ImageInverter/ImageInverter.zip
2. Set iOS Deployment target to 11.0 or higher in both main and extension app
3. Set Extension App as startup project and rebuild the project
4. Deploy it in iOS simulator 
5. Open ImageInverter app in iOS simulator 
6. Enable ImageInverterExtn App in it


### Expected Behavior
ImageInverterExtn App should launch in iOS Simulator and Image should
be Inverted
 
### Actual Behavior
Blank screen is displayed when ImageInverterExtn loaded 
Screencast: https://www.screencast.com/t/BweketBj

### Environment

VSFM:  https://gist.github.com/parasAmbhore/a5207b50c330667ed6acd6393e3c5def
VS for windows: https://gist.github.com/parasAmbhore/e51d16f2541d49850a0a5277806cce00

### Build Logs

[VSFM_logs.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/files/1683392/VSFM_logs.zip)


### Regression: from d15-4
This issue was reported in VSTS  against VS for windows for d15-5, BUGID https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/510257. Since it is reproducible in both VSFMac and VS for Windows filing it against XI.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[registrar] Register models in the static registrar." (#3386) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Opened pull request "[static registrar] Compute the conversion methods for smart enums and embed those as token references in the generated code." (#3385) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Converting to and from smart enums and their corresponding native value
requires knowing the conversion function, since each smart enum has its own
conversion function.

The dynamic registrar can do this at runtime, but it's something that can be
computed in the static registrar at build time, so do that. The static
registrar will now embed the metadata token (as a token reference) in the
generated code, which can be used at runtime to find the conversion method,
without requiring anything from dynamic registrar.

This requires some refactoring in the conversion methods to allow passing more
information around (the `context` parameter in the conversion functions, which
the smart enum conversion methods now use for the token reference).

It turns out this is a massive improvement (although the scenarios where this
is relevant are rare): a simple test case [1] is 300x faster (from ~30s to
0.1s).
